thread.title: BRUSSELS BLACKOUT: ‘Panic STRIKES EU capital’ after power failure leaves city in darkness
thread.title_full: BRUSSELS BLACKOUT: ‘Panic STRIKES EU capital’ after power failure leaves city in darkness

title: BRUSSELS BLACKOUT: ‘Panic STRIKES EU capital’ after power failure leaves city in darkness
text:
BRUSSELS BLACKOUT: ‘Panic STRIKES EU capital’ after power failure leaves city in darkness BRUSSELS BLACKOUT: ‘Panic STRIKES EU capital’ after power failure leaves city in darkness BRUSSELS was plunged into darkness after a “massive power cut” left huge areas of the city without power. PUBLISHED: 01:46, Fri, Feb 10, 2017 | UPDATED: 02:36, Fri, Feb 10, 2017 TWITTER*JACK LOVELL Many northern suburbs were left without power 
Security fears swept across the EU capital as residents reporting hearing sirens across the city. 
Repair teams are now working quickly to restore power to the Belgian capital after a power network operator confirmed there is a fault in the grid. Related articles Soho and Piccadilly plunged into darkness during London power cut 
Elia, a Belgian high-voltage transmission system operator, tweeted: “The blackout in Brussels is not a terrorist attack but a technical error in one of the high-voltage substations.” 
The number of people without power is unknown but the suburbs of Evere, Woluwe-Saint-Lambert and Schaerbeek have all been affected. 
Sibelga, a gas and electricity service operator in the city, is keeping people updated via Twitter and said power is slowly being restored. TWITTER*MATTHIEU HENKENS Some street lamps still had power but many homes were plunged into darkness 
The main power cut is believed to have happened at around 9.45pm GMT (10.45pm local time), while there was also a smaller outage at earlier in the evening which was resolved by around 7.30pm GMT (8.30pm local time). 
Both the European Commission and the European Council headquarters still have power, according to reports. TWITTER 
Dozens of people in the city took to social media to post extraordinary pictures of the blackout. 
Citizens were urged to stay calm as repair teams worked to restore power. TWITTER*NOUR BAKR New £270m home of the European Council Thu, December 8, 2016 This will become the new home of the European Council from January 2017, almost 13 years after EU bosses first decided they needed a bigger meeting-place due to the bloc’s growing size Play slideshow 1 of 11 
The city has been on high terror alert after three coordinated suicide attacks killed 35 people and left more than 300 injured last year. 
The bombings were the deadliest terror attack in Belgium’s history and came just months after a similar attack in Paris. Related articles
